title: Life on antiretroviral therapy: People's adaptive coping and adjustment to living with HIV as a chronic condition in Wakiso District, Uganda
abstractText:
The research in Entebbe, Uganda, will analyse the experiences of people living with HIV following access to life-saving antiretroviral therapy (ART).  The study aims to understand how people have responded to a new chance at life, what factors enable people to adjust to living with HIV as a chronic condition, and what support measures affect this adjustment.  The study aims to inform ART delivery policy and practice in resource-constrained settings.

Adjustment to a new life on ART poses medical, social and economic challenges, especially in settings of poverty. People must take treatment for the rest of their lives, and they are usually recovering after a period of serious illness and disruption to their social and economic lives.

Three ART delivery sites with different modes of delivery and support will be compared. A quasi-experimental research design will be used to compare people affected and unaffected by HIV and ART, and uses complementary qualitative and quantitative methods.

The research will involve collaboration between four partners: The School of International Development at UEA, and in Uganda the Medical Research Council, The AIDS Support Organisation and a Ministry of Health hospital.
findingsText:
Numerous findings are emerging from the analysis of the qualitative and quantitative data. 



The the first set of findings to be written up will be in a paper that presents quality of life (QoL) and depression score data for people living with HIV (PLWH) in Uganda (n=260), and compares them to scores from a community control sample (n=160). The data reveal a counter-intuitive finding: PLWH reported significantly higher QoL scores and lower depressions cores than the community control group. 



The paper will present the quantitave QoL and depression measures, and then explain these differences using qualitative illness narrative data and theoretical insights from health psychology literature to explore why PLWH report higher QoL scores.



A system of service provision dedicated to PLWH partly explained the high QoL scores. The narratives also reveal cognitive processes that explain the higher scores. The concept of 'response shift' from QoL research is applied to the data. This concept refers to how people adjust and find additional or new meaning and benefit to life, following a diagnosis of serious illness and treatment, and despite adversity.



The paper will be one of the first to use insights from health psychology to understand cognitive self-management processes and adjustment to living with HIV on ART in resource-limited settings. It combines these with more widely used sociological approaches to illness self-management. The findings have relevance to the practices of service providers and patients on ART programmes.
